textline.text: Department of Sociology· Mergenthaler Hall· 3400 North Charles St· Baltimore, MD 21211
Eva Rosen
Johns Hopkins University
evarosen@jhu.edu
Postdoctoral Fellow
Johns Hopkins University
Poverty and Inequality Research Lab, Department of Sociology
Postdoctoral Fellow
Harvard University
Harvard College Fellows Program, Department of Sociology
EMPLOYMENT
EDUCATION
Ph.D. in Sociology and Social Policy
Harvard University
Dissertation: “The Rise of the Horizontal Ghetto: Poverty in a Post-Public Housing Era”
Committee: Matthew Desmond, Kathryn Edin, Michèle Lamont, Mary Waters (chair), and William
Julius Wilson
B.A. summa cum laude
Barnard College of Columbia University
A.M. in Sociology
Harvard University
Committee: Mary Waters (chair), Michèle Lamont, and Robert Sampson
RESEARCH INTERESTS
Urban sociology, poverty, inequality, race, ethnicity, immigration, culture, crime, social policy, social theory.
PUBLICATIONS
Books
Rosen, Eva. The Horizontal Ghetto: American Poverty in a Post-Public Housing Era. Under contract with
Princeton University Press.
Journal Articles
Rosen, Eva. “Rigging the Rules of the Game: How Landlords Geographically Sort Low-Income
Renters.” City & Community 13(4): 310-340.
* ESS Candace Rogers Student Paper Award, Honorary Mention
Rosen, Eva and Sudhir Venkatesh. “A Perversion of Choice: Sex Work offers Just Enough in
Chicago’s Urban Ghetto.” Journal of Contemporary Ethnography. 37(4): 417-441.
Rosen, Eva and Sudhir Venkatesh. “Legal Innovation and the Control of Gang Behavior.” Annual
Review of Law and Social Science. 3: 255-270.
Other Published Writing
Rosen, Eva. “The Power of Landlords.” The Atlantic (Online Edition). June 9, 2015.
Rosen, Eva. “The Real Baltimore Crisis.” The Scholar Strategy Network, Basic Facts Brief.
Bell, Monica, Nathan Fosse, Michèle Lamont and Eva Rosen. “Beyond the Culture of Poverty:
Meaning-Making among Low-Income Populations around Family, Neighborhood, and Work.”
Blackwell Encyclopedia of Race, Ethnicity and Nationalism, Ed. John Stone, Rutledge Dennis, Polly
Rizova, and Anthony Smith. Wiley.
Rosen, Eva. “Reverse Selection: Landlords and the Sorting of HCV Renters.” Poverty and Race
Research Action Council 24(1): 3-7.
Rosen, Eva. “Gans, Herbert.” Sage Encyclopedia of Urban Studies, 1. Ed. Ray Hutchinson. Sage
Publications, 285-287.
Works in Progress
“Redefining Residential Mobility: Narratives of Neighborhood Violence and Choice.” (Under review at the
American Sociological Review)
“The Residential Decisions of Unauthorized Migrants: Hiding within American Racial Hierarchies.” With
Asad Asad. (Under review at Social Problems)
Eastern Sociological Society, Candace Rogers Student Paper Award, Honorary Mention
National Science Foundation, Graduate Student Research Fellowship, Honorable Mention
Barnard College, Summa Cum Laude
Sciences-Po Paris, International Program, Diploma with Honors
“‘This is How We Behave:’ Landlord-Tenant Relations and the New Paternalism.” With Philip Garboden.
“Social Isolation, Spatial Proximity, & the Durability of Neighborhood Attainment after Hurricane Katrina.”
AWARDS & DISTINCTIONS
GRANTS & FELLOWSHIPS
External Funding
Furman Center for Urban Gov. & Policy, “Landlords and the Geography of Opportunity” $25,000
Joint Center for Housing Studies, John Meyer Fellowship, $5000
National Science Foundation, Dissertation Improvement Grant, $6920
Dept. of Housing and Urban Development, “Landlords and the Geography of Opportunity” $400,000
Barnard College Alumnae Association, Fellowship for Graduate Study, $5000
Taubman Center for Urban Policy and Governance, Dissertation Fellowship, $10,000
Department of Housing and Urban Development, Dissertation Research Grant, $25,000
Horowitz Foundation for Social Policy, Research Grant, $4000
Harvard Graduate School of Arts and Sciences Dissertation Completion Fellowship, $30,982
Harvard Kennedy School Malcolm Weiner Center, Research Grant with Kathryn Edin, $7000
Harvard Real Estate Academic Initiative, Research Grant $4000
Harvard Multidisciplinary Program in Inequality & Social Policy, NSF-IGERT Grant, $5000
Harvard University Merit/Graduate Society, Term-time Research Fellowship, $11,845
Perry Family Fellowship for Sociology and Social Policy, Graduate Fellowship
Harvard University Center for American Politics (CAPS), Seed Grant, $1000
Internal Funding
SELECTED PRESENTATIONS
Rosen, Eva and Philip Garboden. “‘This is How We Behave:’ Landlord-Tenant Relations and the
New Paternalism.” American Sociological Association, Chicago, IL.
Rosen, Eva and Asad Asad. “Social Isolation, Spatial Proximity, and the Durability of
Neighborhood Attainment after Hurricane Katrina.” Eastern Sociological Society, New York, NY.
Rosen, Eva. “Neighborhood Effects on Choice and Churning.” American Sociological Association.
San Francisco, CA.
Rosen, Eva. “Housing Policy in the Land of Opportunity: Landlords’ role in geographic sorting
and the re-concentration of poverty.” Eastern Sociological Society, Baltimore, MD.
Rosen, Eva. “The Rules of the Game: Landlords and the Geographic Sorting of Voucher
Holders.” Furman Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy, New York University. New York, NY.
Rosen, Eva. “Landlords and the Geographic Sorting of Voucher Holders.” Urban Affairs
Association. San Francisco, California.
Rosen, Eva. “Resilience and Relocation Decisions in the Aftermath of Hurricane Katrina.”
Roundtable session, “Natural and Unnatural Disasters.” Eastern Sociological Society. New York, NY.
Rosen, Eva. “Unpacking Perceptions: Heterogeneity in the Construction of Disorder Among in
Chicago.” American Sociological Association. Las Vegas.
Rosen, Eva. “Relocation Decisions in the Aftermath of Hurricane Katrina.” Returning to Katrina:
Bringing Hurricane Katrina Back to the Community. The University of Mississippi, Gulf Port.
Rosen, Eva. “The Perception of Disorder in Chicago: Understanding Spatial Variation.”
Geographic Information Systems (GIS) Summer Institute, Center for Geographic Analysis, Harvard.
Rosen, Eva. “Perceptions of Disorder and Crime in a Multi-ethnic Neighborhood.” Summer
Workshop on Immigration and Social Change in Britain and the U.S. Manchester, England.
Rosen, Eva. “Incarceration, Social Control, and Space in Brownsville Brooklyn.” Race and
Inequality Workshop, Harvard University.
Rosen, Eva. “What’s Money Got to Do With It? Sex Work in Socioeconomic Context.” Sex
Work Matters: Beyond Divides. New School and CUNY Graduate Center, New York.
Rosen, Eva. “Sex Work Offers Just Enough in Chicago’s Urban Ghetto.” Eastern Sociological
Association. Boston, MA.
RESEARCH EXPERIENCE
Landlords and the Geography of Opportunity, Johns Hopkins University, 2013 - 2015
Co-PI with PI’s Kathryn Edin and Stefanie DeLuca; Managed research team across three field sites: Dallas,
Baltimore, and Cleveland
How Parents House Kids, MacArthur Network on Children and Families, 2013 - 2014
Co-PI with PI’s Kathryn Edin and Stefanie DeLuca: Managed Dallas field site, 8 researchers, 70 interviews
Moving to Opportunity, 10-year qualitative review, Harvard University, 2010 - 2011
Research with Professor Kathryn Edin; Conducted in-depth interviews with low-income youth in Baltimore.
Resilience in Survivors of Hurricane Katrina (RISK), Harvard University, 2009 - 2014
Research Assistant for Prof. Mary Waters; Conducted in-depth qualitative interviews; data analysis and coding.
Successful Societies, Harvard University, 2008 - 2009
Research Assistant for Professor Michèle Lamont on cross-national comparison of “successful societies.”
Qualitative study of the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) Study, Harvard University, 2007 - 2008
Research with Professor Kathryn Edin; conducted in-depth interviews with low-income families on financial
expenditures and the EITC.
Center for Urban Research and Policy, ISERP, Columbia University, 2005 - 2007
Associate Director
• Coordinated the Urban Research Workshop: Sustainability in an International Urban Context, where
undergraduates learn about diverse research methodologies and conduct comparative research on the
theoretical and practical dimensions of urban issues.
• Conducted study on prisoner re-entry in South Bronx using GIS to analyze spatial movements.
• Coordinated a large-scale study on Chicago Public Housing Plan for Transformation, documenting the
relocation of former public housing residents.
TEACHING EXPERIENCE
Department of Sociology, Harvard University
Lecturer
Introduction to Sociology
Junior Tutorial: Urban Social Problems and Public Policy
Introduction to Urban Sociology
Spring 2015
Spring 2015
Fall 2014
Senior Thesis Writing Tutorial
Senior Thesis Writing Tutorial
Instructor
Teaching Fellow
Medicine and Disease in Social Context, Professor Nicholas Christakis
Models of Social Science Research Design (*Head TF), Professor Mary Waters
Urban Social Problems, Professor Kathryn Edin
Models of Social Science Research Design, Professor Tim Nelson
Senior Thesis Advising
Advised 6 senior theses, one of which was awarded the Hoopes Prize for undergraduate excellence
Departmental Qualitative Research Advisor
Institute for Quantitative Social Science (IQSS), Harvard University
Teaching Fellow
Qualitative Methods and Research Design, Professor Natasha Warikoo
January 2011 & 2012
Spring 2011
Fall 2010
Spring 2010
Fall 2009
2006 - present
2007 - present
2012 - present
2008 - present
Lycée Léonard de Vinci, St. Germain en Laye, France
Professor of High School English

American Sociological Association
Eastern Sociological Association
Urban Affairs Association
SERVICE POSITIONS
Occasional Reviewer
City & Community; American Journal of Sociology; American Sociological Review;

Graduate Student Coordinator, Harvard University
Migration and Immigrant Incorporation Workshop
Study Group on Inclusion and Exclusion in an Expanded Europe
SKILLS
Languages
French: Fluent in reading, writing, speaking.
Spanish: Intermediate skills in speaking, reading, writing.
Technology: ATLAS.ti, MAXQDA, Stata, ArcGIS, Dreamweaver, Photoshop, Microsoft Office.
